abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is highly
            satisfactory, with likely sustainability and high
            institutional development impacts. Lessons emphasize the
            following. Most of the project success stands on the strong
            government commitment, and ownership, demonstrated by the
            support sought by the government in framing a strategy for
            managing economic shocks, and the introduction of
            legislative changes to support the capital markets
            component. Furthermore, the proactive analysis work
            conducted by the Bank at the early stages, on the impact of
            global financial shocks on emerging markets, proved not only
            relevant for the Peruvian experience (since it was
            motivated, based on the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis), but
            helped focus on the highest impact issues, and speed up loan
            preparation. As such, concerns about banking system
            vulnerabilities, emphasized implementation of preventive
            supervision, and bank resolution by the Superintendency of
            Banking and Insurance: rather than limiting conditionality
            to the preparation of new legislation, the project also
            enhanced actual bank resolution practices. Nonetheless, it
            would be desirable that new, or follow-up operations be
            interlinked with previous reform programs, to ensure reform
            benefits, i.e., more sector related work could have been
            provided for the private pension system, which was at its
            early stages, having been initiated under a previous
            operation. In light of unclear options in the development of
            capital markets, it was wise to focus on studies, and action
            plans, to then prepare follow-up projects to implement such plans.
